div.head: Mercurius Rusticus: The downfall of Tythes.

argument.p: The Country-man discovering the pride, lewdness, covetousness, and ambition of the fat beneficed Priests, incroaching Tythe-mongers, and oppressing Impropriators, &c.

lg.l: Synods and Classes, Knaves and Fooles,
Their dearest Darling now must lose
The Country Farmer then will well
Were by him to be sold,
St. Peters Keyes he'd freely lend
To them would give him Gold.

div.p:
HEre's brave News, my Neighbors (saith honest Jack Bumpkin) God blesse our New Parliament, an Act is now comming forth for abolishing the payment of Tyths, under which heavy burden we have so long grievously groaned; but now Mr. Parson
saith he'l shut up the Church doors, and send St. Peter the Keyes; but my Country-man can tell him 'tis not the place, but the persons assembled together that make a Church; nay, he hath learnt so much Latine, and can prove it to be Divinity too; that utinam omnes populi essent Prophetae, he can shew you Canonicall Scrtpture for it, which is of more authority than Mr. Parsons Institution and Induction: Nay, but Mr. Symon Magus the old Symoniacall Priest of H. and B. did aver it to be sacriledge and blaspheamy for any one to read the word of God in the Publick Congregation (vulgo the Church) unlesse he were one that had received Holy Orders; you could not have heard so much superstition out of any mans mouth, but a Tythmonger; but now the Tythes must down, Mr. Parson sighes, he sees a good Harvest towards, and now parvas spes habet, &c. his hopes faile him, that he shall not reap the sweat of other mens brows; and Mounseir Avidus the covetous Patron and Impropriator fears least he should lose his thumping fnt Benefices, whereby he might bestow a Daughter to a rich Parson, the loving Impropriator of Sutton in Hampshire, is now to Statesman (but he's a Clerk himselfe) must part with his 400. pound per Annum, and the idle lazy Drone, late Dean of Armagh, must learn to rise more early in the mornings, and study to preach for his Living himselfe, and not have 300 pounds per Annum Tythes, to maintaine him to lye a bed and drinke Sack and Tobacco, and hire a poor Pedagogue for 20 l. per Annum: But some of these Priests are grown sawcy, proud, and impudent (and so they
were alwayes) the chanting Sir Ignoramus of Chittingfold, for want of better matter to run out his houre-glasse, began to expostulate with his Congregation about the taking away of Tythes, and displacing him, as some honest men had endeavoured to do, not for his goodness; he plainly, boldly, and for sound Doctrine affirmed (that they should find he was a stout Knave) and as I am informed most of his Auditors confirmed his words to be an Orthodox Truth; and for my part I verily believe it, this fellow is fitter for a Parrator, and more like a Barrator then a Minister, for instead of indeavouring to make peace and love, and to continue amity and friendship amongst his Neighbours, he like Fryar Rush, is the beautifeu that sets all of them together by the ears, there's not a Law suit heard of thereabouts, but he's at one end of it; you shall be more sure to finde him foaming at the mouth amongst his Lawyers, then in his study.

But now Doctour Apollos, a grave learned Divine, Bishop of K. near London, to save his 200 l. per Annum, rides up and down in his Coach, and lately bribed three honest Lawyers to demonstrate to the Court, that though there be many of them Knaves and Fooles, yet there be some wise learned men also. Then there is Mr. Grace, the flourishing ignorant Favourite, who by his friend, or his purse (not for his deserts in Learning or Honesty) attaineth a Benefice; he is a resemblance to the Law favourite, who for his Learning deserves rather to be an Auditor, then an ignorant Orator; sed fortuna favet fatuis, insomuch that he is a Preacher or practicer of Fortune; the truth whereof is, that the
disease of his friend is the end of his practice, Amicus us{que} ad mortem; and of this Ignoramus, and Sir Ignoramus, I motto thus; Pari Jugo sociantur Asini: This Sir Ignoramus you must conceive hath commenced Batchelour of Art in ignorance, yet he hath learned a Cambridge probo; but both he and his Kinsman in ignorance, wanting not their favouring friends to help them into a Benefice, when many a learned and studious Gentleman wanting helpe of Friends, might sit without both, so much is this froward Age we live in to be condemned, the more we see Ignorance preferred before Learning and Virtue, and dull-pated covetous Jobber-noles, unworthyly advanced to places of profit and dignity, when many a learned Muse sits in his study, destitute of either; but here I only tax-time of partiality.

But since it is so, that the long hopes of the Husbandmen are almost come to effect, and Sir Priest must be one of his Tyth-mongring, his pride and stoutness amongst his Neighbours (if he intends or hopes to live by his preaching, he must fall to his study; and not like that covetous proud Symoniacall Doctour of Cressingham, and two or three Benefices more, that used to ride up and down the fields, to see where the best Corn was, and then takes his Tyths by the Acre, and force his poor Parishioners to pay him so.

And now Hugh Adoniram the Scribe sweats in his grease, like a tallow Candle in the Sun, for fear he shall lose his 400 l. per annum, which (not for his goodnesse) hee lately got in Wiltshire, leaving his flock at Fulham, to starve, or else be fed by the glassman
of Hamersmith; for do what they will, Adoniram cares not, hee delights to be where there is most money to bee got, as all other Priests of late years do; nay many of them within these few years have got a trick to shift their places as commonly as a Lady doth her Smocks, or at least her Maids; but you must alwayes observe, tis to get the better Benifice in the mystery, although they pretend and give out it is to seat themselves amongst a more conformable religious people in the History, but the meaning is such as are more conformable to pay them their Tithes.

But here I cannot overpasse to discover the wisdome of Adoniram, and to let you know his wonderfull policy, whereby he would demonstrate to the people, that there are some crafty covetous Knaves, amongst the Clergy, as well as ignorant Fooles; he was no sooner warm in his 400 l. per Annum, but he speedily bethinks with himself how to keep it, hearing the clamour of the Countrey, and generall crying out of the burden of Tythes, and because he saw a good Harvest towards, he forthwith frames and contrives a Petition to the Supream Authority of England the late Parliament, in the names of the grand Jury men of the County of Wilts. thereby to cloud his owne covetous villainy, praying thereby that the ministers might be encouraged to preach the Gospel, by having their Tythes duly payd; whereas all the Jurymen, unlesse two or three that were impropriators, were of the contrary opinion, knowing very well the grievances of the Country thereby; but Adoniram made bold to use
their names and hands to it, and procured two or three of his Saints to deliver it, and came himselfe to London in expectation of some Order therein for his profit; but his hopes were frustrated, for that very day the late Parliament was dissolved, he came too late to the Parliament doore at Westminster, studying mischiefe like a Bore in the Oates, and found the doore shut, and his birds flowne.

This fellow and two or three hundred more of his Comrades spent almost five yeares, and cost the State four shillings a day a piece, to invent a new frame of Church government; but they proved just like the French Milwright, who because he could make a Mill well, had a Chymera in his braine that he could make such an Engine, as should turne the Spit, draw water out of a Well, and tell the houre of the day as well as any Clock; after he had spent much time and pains about it, hee at last made a Nut-cracker of it: even so did the Learned Synod spend five years about making a Catechisme; but when I was a Schoole-boy, if I had not learned such a one in one quarter of a yeare, I should have been soundly whipt. They might far better have spent their time about translating the Bible, correcting the Errours in it, if they had knowne how; if not, I could have procured one who would have taught them for two shillings per diem, which is but halfe one of their pay: I marvell they are not ashamed (but most of them are shamelesse) to read such nonsence to the people as they doe; as in the first chapter of Luke it's said of Zacharias, that when he was dumb, and his child was to be named, they
made signes to his Father what he would have him called; they read it in our Translation, verse 63. that he asked for writing Tables, and wrote saying, his name is John: how can, or could a dumb man aske for Tables? if hee could, certainly then hee might have told them his name without writing. But because I will informe my Countrey-man the true sence of the words, and to learn Sir Ignoramus more Greeke then the drrunken Priest of Swallowfield ever knew; I tell you the word in the Original is 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 of 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 of 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , id est, Capio, vel peto; it signifies, to take, or seek after; so that 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , which are the words in the Originall, doe signifie (and I am sure is better sence) and he sought after, or tooke a writing Table, &c. for how a dumb man can ask for a thing, seems an impossibility to me; but seeing I have Mr. Adoniram, Mounseir Avidus, Sir Simon Magus, and Sir Ignoramus together; I'le try if I can tosse them like a dog in a blanket, and make them vomit out their non-sence, and rid them of their Ignorance, Pride, and Covetousnesse.

Their Tythes must away; but as for the rest, I doubt I shall strive with an impossibility; Quia ignorantia, avaritia, & superbitas suae herent in nomine, in Capite, & in Cute: therefore I will not spend much labour to reforme Sir Ignoramus, nor Mounseir Avidus neither, counting my labour as endlesse, as the two Maids at Detford, which endeavoured by washing the Blackmore to make him white: But to vent out some passion against Sir Simon Magus for his Simoney, I meane not that person named in the 8. of the Acts of the Apostles, for he offered to give
money to buy the bestowing of the Holy Ghost; this refused not to take mony to bestow a Benefice; so they were of kinne, this a Knight without liveing, that a Knave without grace.

Their Lordships, since they have got down their Masters the Bishops, thought to be every one a Bishop in his Parish, and one of them lorded it so much, that a poor old man grieving thereat, made bold to speak the truth of Mr. Parson, and called him proud foole, but Sir Priest brought an Action against the old man for it, and threatned him so, (the other being not able to defend it) though he knew well enough the words would not bear an Action, that he forced the poor man to composition with him, and to give him a fat Pig & halfe a dozen Chickens, and besides to come and ask him forgiveness in the Publick Congregation, when he was in his Pulpit chanting, as if he would have cursed with Bell, Book, and Candle; then there is Master Plurality, the ingrossing Beneficer, one of the Actors in this Comedy, he is a person compounded out of many particularities into a plurall qualification, dispensation, and non-residence, be the only liberall Sciences in his study: In all these I only ayme at the iniquity of the Times, and by their names to demonstrate their qualities; I suppose no man can religiously be offeeded at me, if they be, I say no more to them, but Adsum qui dixi, in me convertite tela.
